newsitem.title: UK: Lloyd's List newspaper to float stock.
newsitem.headline: Lloyd's List newspaper to float stock.

text.p: LLP Ltd., publisher of Lloyd's List, reputed to be the world's oldest newspaper, said Monday it planned to offer shares on the stock exchange.
It said it had appointed NatWest Markets to advise the company in preparation for a future flotation, and had appointed Cazenove & Co. as corporate brokers.
LLP Ltd. was formerly a subsidiary of the Lloyd's of London insurance market and was target of a management buyout in December 1995.

The company describes itself as the world's leading maritime publisher. It publishes more than 300 international titles in addition to the shipping and insurance newspaper Lloyd's List, which was founded in 1734.

The statement put no value on the company, but the Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported that the float might value the group at more than 100 million pounds ($167 million), noting the management buyout was for 82.5 million pounds ($138 million).
